author: By Daniel Victor
title: How to watch today’s opening ceremony.
description: The curtain-raiser of the 2022 Winter Games will be shorter than usual, but not lacking in bombastic flair.
content: Seven years after Beijing won the hosting rights to the 2022 Winter Games, and two days after competition quietly began with a curling rock sliding down a sheet of ice, China will officially open the Winter Games on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: Lone ISIS Bomber Carried Out Attack at Kabul Airport, Pentagon Says
description: The suicide bombing killed as many as 170 civilians and 13 U.S. troops in the final days of U.S. military involvement in Afghanistan.
content: A single Islamic State suicide bomber carried out the attack at Kabul’s international airport in August that killed 13 U.S. troops and as many as 170 civilians, and was not joined by accomplices firing into the crowd, according to a Pentagon report released on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Rips Rudy Giuliani’s ‘Masked Singer’ Appearance
description: Jimmy Kimmel joked that only Giuliani would attempt to overthrow the government “and then try to rehabilitate his image by singing ‘Shake Your Groove Thing’ dressed as a pineapple.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanne Timmons
title: Why Did a Fish Have Fossilized Feces Where Its Brain Once Was?
description: It’s the first time a vertebrate’s braincase has ever been found full of coprolites, scientists say.
content: It’s a dubious distinction in the fossil record: For the first time, a vertebrate has been found with fecal pellets where its brain once was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg and Charlie Savage
title: Panel Recommends Transfer of Guantánamo Detainee Suspected of 9/11 Role
description: The Biden administration is expected to send the mentally ill detainee, whom the military tortured and so could not be put on trial, to Saudi Arabia as early as March.
content: WASHINGTON — The case of a mentally ill detainee at Guantánamo Bay, Mohammed al-Qahtani, has long confounded the United States government. Suspected of being Al Qaeda’s intended 20th hijacker in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, he was tortured by military interrogators early in his detention at the American naval base in Cuba.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: My Favorite Wholesome, Humiliating Stunt, by the Stars of ‘Jackass’
description: With a new film in the franchise about to hit theaters, we asked them about the torments they remember most fondly.
content: Most of us would call it a nightmare. Steve-O called it a dream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Robert Jimison, Eric Krupke, Luke Vander Ploeg, Lynsea Garrison, Mike Benoist, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Brad Fisher
title: A ‘Zero Covid’ Olympics
description: What it’s like inside China’s Covid superbubble — and whether the nation’s strict approach to the virus can last.
content: Reporters from The Times are joining athletes from around the world as they descend on Beijing for the 2022 Winter Olympics, where they are encountering the strictest and most wide-ranging health requirements ever attempted at an Olympic Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: pro bono
description: This term has appeared in 68 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The term pro bono has appeared in 68 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 15 in “For This Theater Leader, a Mission That Goes Beyond the Stage” by Bob Morris:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber and Karen Weise
title: Amazon Warehouse in Alabama Is Set to Begin Second Union Election
description: Workers overwhelmingly voted down a union last year, but labor regulators threw out the result, citing company misconduct.
content: During the first union election at Amazon’s Bessemer, Ala., warehouse early last year, organizers largely avoided visiting workers at home because Covid was raging and few Americans were vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Love Letter: Remembering Your Mortality
description: Plus: A wedding boom and a flower shortage.
content: Six weeks after getting married, Carol Dunbar learned that her husband was predisposed to develop life-threatening brain aneurysms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Stepping Back to Look Ahead
description: The New York Times’s new Headway initiative investigates challenges around the world — and evaluates our progress toward solving them.
content: In 2018, despite having recently published a series of articles on how climate change was challenging the world’s cities that was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize, Michael Kimmelman, The New York Times’s architecture critic, felt unsatisfied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manan Luthra
title: Captain Cook’s Ship Caught in Center of a Maritime Rift
description: After researchers in Australia reported finding the wreck of the Endeavour off Rhode Island, their U.S. partners issued a startling rebuke.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — When the British explorer James Cook set out in 1768 in search of an “unknown southern land” called Terra Australis Incognita, he sailed on a navy research vessel called the HMB Endeavour. More than 90 people were on board the ship, described by some historians as homely but sturdy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: ISIS leader dead in U.S. raid.
content: President Biden announced that the leader of ISIS, Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi, had died during an assault in Syria carried out by about two dozen American commandos. Rescue workers said women and children were among at least 13 people killed during the raid in Atmeh, a town close to the border with Turkey in rebel-held Idlib Province.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha C. White
title: Extreme Weather and Rising Insurance Rates Squeeze Retirees
description: Homeowners’ insurance in high-risk states is becoming prohibitively expensive for older Americans who want to keep their homes.
content: As a money management professional, Eric Diton helps his clients manage complex personal finance issues. But he’s finding that more of them are frustrated by a surprisingly mundane budget item: homeowners’ insurance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Michael Avenatti Is Found Guilty of Stealing From Stormy Daniels
description: They were once united in an effort to topple Donald J. Trump. But even then, a jury found, Mr. Avenatti was stealing from his famous client.
content: Four years ago, Stormy Daniels and Michael Avenatti presented a united front against President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Californians Feel Less Optimistic About the Pandemic Than They Did Last Spring
description: A new survey finds that Californians are increasingly uncertain that the worst is behind them.
content: As you’re probably aware by now, Covid-19 infections and hospitalizations are plummeting in California — the first pandemic-related good news in months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: If Everything Is ‘Trauma,’ Is Anything?
description: “Love bombing,” “gaslighting,” “emotional labor.” On the pathologizing of everyday behaviors.
content: The man had been effusive, at first — sending compliments, engaging in witty back-and-forths, making a playlist that included that song by Mazzy Star (you know the one). And then, suddenly, he wasn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The Backlash Against C.R.T. Shows That Republicans Are Losing Ground
description: The suppression and subversion of Black history in favor of an inauthentic rendering of the American past has a long history in and of itself.
content: Since January 2021, according to an analysis by Education Week, Republican lawmakers in 37 states have introduced dozens of bills to restrict teaching on the subject of race and racism under the guise of opposition to “critical race theory.” In 14 states, restrictions have either passed into law or been imposed through either executive action or on the authority of a state education commission. One such law, passed in Texas, prohibits teaching that “slavery and racism are anything other than deviations from, betrayals of, or failures to live up to the authentic founding principles of the United States, which include liberty and equality.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A Sinking Boat Caught Her Eye During a Zoom Call
description: All three crew members of a fishing boat named Bing Bing were rescued after a woman working from home saw the vessel capsize off Scituate, Mass. “She saved our lives,” one survivor said.
content: On a very clear day, Pam Harght can see Boston from her third-floor home office, which is roughly 30 miles to the southeast, but her eyes darted away from a Zoom call with her boss on Tuesday to the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Amanda Holpuch
title: Minneapolis Suspends No-Knock Warrants After Police Killing
description: Amir Locke, 22, was fatally shot as the police carried out a search warrant. He was lying under a blanket until an officer kicked the couch, revealing a gun, body camera video shows.
content: Mayor Jacob Frey of Minneapolis on Friday announced a moratorium on no-knock warrants one day after the Police Department released body camera footage of its SWAT team fatally shooting a man who was lying on a couch under a blanket during an early-morning raid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers
title: In Beijing, Olympic Spectacle and Global Power Games
description: The opening of the Winter Games gave Xi Jinping and Vladimir V. Putin a chance to cement their partnership against Western censure.
content: BEIJING — China’s leader, Xi Jinping, opened an Olympic Games on Friday intended to celebrate his country’s increasingly assured global status standing defiantly with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, in an increasingly ideological contest with the United States and its allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Notes Economic Success as Employment and Wages Rise
description: President Biden is celebrating a historic year of job gains and trying to shift the narrative amid high inflation and a lingering virus that have many consumers glum.
content: President Biden on Friday celebrated unexpectedly rapid January hiring and new data that showed historically strong employment gains over the past year, seizing on good news at a moment when consumers are nervous about their prospects thanks to a lingering pandemic and persistent inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Léontine Gallois
title: Apathy and Anger in France’s Election Everytown
description: Auxerre has backed the winner in every French presidential race for 40 years. This time, the town’s politics are drifting right, and many struggling residents see little to vote for.
content: AUXERRE, France — With its magnificent 13th-century Gothic cathedral and its prominent statue of Paul Bert, one of the founders of France’s secular school system, Auxerre seems to encapsulate French history. Half-timbered houses line picturesque riverbanks. Vines roll across the surrounding countryside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Jamaica, known for bobsledding, adds an Alpine skier to its team.
description: You can be forgiven if you think that Jamaica’s flag-bearer is a bobsledder. When it comes to the Winter Games and the tropical island nation, pretty much everyone thinks of the group of bobsledders from the 1988 Olympics who inspired the Disney film “Cool Runnings.”
content: You can be forgiven if you think that Jamaica’s flag-bearer is a bobsledder. When it comes to the Winter Games and the tropical island nation, pretty much everyone thinks of the group of bobsledders from the 1988 Olympics who inspired the Disney film “Cool Runnings.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: On Paper, They Were All Wrong. But in Time, Just Right.
description: Edgar Alonzo wanted to settle down and raise children when he met Beatriz Rivera, who was in the midst of a divorce and already had a grown child.
content: Edgar Alonzo was moving in for a cheek-to-cheek moment with Beatriz Rivera when he got his first indication that they weren’t going to see eye to eye. The two were at his cousin’s birthday party in January 2014, and she had agreed to dance with him. He suggested she take her heels off. She said, “If you can’t handle tall women, you shouldn’t ask them to dance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Book of Love’ Review: Lust (Eventually) in Translation
description: Unbeknown to the author of an uninspired romance novel, the book takes a sharp turn into erotic territory in its Spanish-language release.
content: “Who wrote the book of love?,” the Monotones once mused. It couldn’t possibly be Henry Copper (Sam Claflin), a stodgy author whose debut romance novel is so devoid of passion that it sells only two copies in his native Britain. But when an audacious translator named María Rodríguez (Verónica Echegui) reimagines Henry’s chaste love story as soapy erotica, he becomes a surprise sensation in Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman and Jenny Vrentas
title: ‘All He’s Looking For Is a Sincere Shot’
description: Those close to Brian Flores say his lawsuit against the N.F.L. is in keeping with the sense of moral rectitude he learned from his mother as he grew up in a Brooklyn housing project.
content: During his first preseason as the Miami Dolphins’ head coach, in 2019, Brian Flores spoke with emotion about the social injustice he faced as a young Black and Latino man in the distressed Brownsville section of Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Covid-19 Commission Modeled on 9/11 Inquiry Draws Bipartisan Backing
description: A broad, bipartisan group of senators is coalescing around a plan for an independent panel to investigate the origins of the coronavirus and the U.S. response.
content: WASHINGTON — A broad and bipartisan group of senators is coalescing around legislation to create a high-level independent commission, modeled after the one that examined the Sept. 11 attacks, with broad powers to investigate the origins of the coronavirus pandemic and the response across the Trump and Biden administrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sal Cataldi
title: The Reinvention of Sammy Buttons, Master of Sidewalk Funk
description: He started a bike messenger company in the 1990s. But the death of a friend, followed by Covid, inspired him to pursue his passion.
content: If it weren’t for the pandemic, Sam Pritchard might still be weaving through the streets of Manhattan as a bike messenger. But March 2020 and the subsequent emptying out of office buildings forced Mr. Pritchard, who like many other businesspeople relied on the bustling commerce of Midtown, to pivot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: What’s in a name? For Taiwan, a lot.
description: Officials from the self-governing island worry that China might use the Games as a linguistic opportunity to assert its claim over Taiwan.
content: A week ago, Taiwan said it would not participate in the opening ceremony of the Winter Games in Beijing. Then the island democracy reversed its decision, citing pressure from the International Olympic Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Architects at a prominent New York firm drop their unionization bid.
description: Citing a “powerful anti-union campaign,” workers at SHoP Architects withdrew a petition for an election, but organizing continues at other firms in the industry.
content: Less than two months after seeking to form the only union at a prominent U.S. architecture firm, workers at SHoP Architects, in New York, have formally ended their effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Ivan Penn
title: President Biden extends solar tariffs, with major caveats.
description: The Biden administration extended tariffs on imported solar products but made changes to exempt many more products from the levies, a decision that angered some domestic producers.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden announced Friday that he would extend tariffs on imported solar products first imposed during the Trump administration but would reduce the scope of products affected by the levies, a decision aimed at balancing his goals for bolstering domestic manufacturing with speeding up the transition toward clean energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Pennsylvania Doctor Accused of Prescribing Ivermectin for Covid Is Fired
description: Tower Health Medical Group said in a statement that it learned of the allegations on Wednesday. After an investigation, the doctor’s employment was “terminated effective immediately.”
content: A Pennsylvania doctor accused of prescribing ivermectin and hydroxychloroquine to treat Covid-19, two drugs that regulators have called not safe for treating the disease, was fired this week, a regional health system said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Thousands of Students Missing Out on College Grants, Study Finds
description: The number of students filling out the Fafsa form has fallen in the pandemic, and the form is used to determine who gets federal Pell Grants, which are aimed at the needy.
content: Hundreds of thousands of students are missing out on free college aid because they are not completing a pesky federal form known as the Fafsa, a new analysis finds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor, Steven Lee Myers and Alan Blinder
title: Pelosi warns U.S. athletes not to anger China’s government with protests.
description: The House speaker said protests could prompt reprisals from a “ruthless” Chinese government.
content: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi discouraged Olympic athletes from protesting at the opening ceremony in Beijing on Thursday, saying that it wasn’t worth the risk of reprisal from a “ruthless” Chinese government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: With a missile shot, Ukraine sends a public warning to Russia.
description: As the United States and others step up military aid to Ukraine, the deliveries are more overt, and Ukraine is staging public weapons demonstrations for the media.
content: YAVORIV, Ukraine — With television cameras rolling, a Ukrainian soldier heaved an America-made missile launcher onto his shoulder and pressed a red button. The missile streaked out and blew a target — a pile of tires — to smithereens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather and Andrew Das
title: Winter Olympics kick off first full day with competition in nearly every sport.
description: The first gold medal will be handed out as women compete in the skiathlon. The U.S. skier Jessie Diggins, a star in 2018, will have her first chance at a medal.
content: So that’s it for the warm-up: the pyrotechnics and the puffer jackets, the calls for unity and the power politics, the Italians in their tricolor Armani capes and the American Samoan in, well, not much of anything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch Time Stand Still in ‘The Worst Person in the World’
description: The director Joachim Trier narrates a fanciful sequence from his film, starring Renate Reinsve.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Dunbar
title: Loving Him More When He Walks Out the Door
description: A daily reminder of mortality can be more gift than burden.
content: Six weeks after we married, my husband got a phone call from his mother, and we rushed to the hospital. His aunt Lona lay in the intensive care unit after a bad headache at breakfast turned out to be a ruptured brain aneurysm, and there was nothing more the doctors could do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Seen From Space: Huge Methane Leaks
description: A European satellite reveals sites in the United States, Russia, Central Asia and elsewhere that are “ultra emitters” of methane. That could help fight climate change.
content: If the world is going to make a dent in emissions of methane, a potent planet-warming gas, targeting the largest emitters would likely be the most cost-effective. But there’s a basic problem: How to find them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez
title: U.S. broadcast coverage Friday includes curling and the opening ceremony.
description: Figure skating’s team event, featuring the world champion Nathan Chen, will be rebroadcast at 4 p.m. Eastern.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Friday with curling, figure skating and the opening ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Help. I’ve Fallen for That Cadillac Escalade.
description: I took a top-of-the-line Cadillac Escalade on a two-week road trip. Unfortunately for the planet, I loved it.
content: I was not prepared to fall head over heels for the Cadillac Escalade. It’s not my kind of car — or, at least, it’s not supposed to be. The Escalade is one of the largest, heaviest, least efficient and most expensive S.U.V.s on the road. It is also among the most unembarrassedly decadent, the ride of choice for Manhattan bigwigs and reality-TV housewives, the sort of car that rappers, movie stars and professional athletes buy for their mothers after making it big.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Isabelia Herrera, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Kamasi Washington Blasts Into a Fresh Era, and 13 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Koffee, Lucy Dacus, Sasami and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Bang Petersen
title: The End of the Pandemic May Tear Us Apart
description: Denmark is moving on from the pandemic. Not all countries can easily follow.
content: For countries with high vaccination rates, 2022 may be the last year when strong measures are required against Covid-19. The end of the pandemic, however, will not come easily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: City Ballet Gets a Modern Dance Fix
description: A new work by the Ailey veteran Jamar Roberts shared a program with revivals by Pam Tanowitz and Kyle Abraham.
content: Clearly, the choreographer Jamar Roberts had a feeling about what the world needed now: a lift, a boost, a jolt of hope. Who would disagree? It’s February, and the pandemic is still out there, faded but always looming. At New York City Ballet, Roberts translates the need for pleasure into a dance in which the jazz composer Wayne Shorter’s music drives a cast of eight — first in solos and duets, then in trios and, finally, as a collective — to achieve a state of abandon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Meta’s Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Quarter
description: Facebook’s stock crash points to a rocky path ahead as it goes all in on the metaverse.
content: At some point, the jig is up for almost every highflying tech company (consider that Cisco was, for a time in 2000, the world’s most valuable company). That’s usually because executives put on blinders to one constant rule of innovation I’ve observed: The young devour the old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: This Police Captain’s Plan to Stop Gun Violence Uses More Than Handcuffs
description: An N.Y.P.D. precinct in Brooklyn is seeing promise in a different kind of response to a shooting last spring: paying 15 teenagers to attend a “healing circle.”
content: Classes had just been dismissed at a high school in Brooklyn for teenagers who needed a second chance, when a student named Devonte Lewis stepped outside and into the cross hairs of his rivals. Two teenage gunmen opened fire, the police said, killing Mr. Lewis, who was 17.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Younger Americans Benefited Less From Booster Shots Than Older People
description: Among those under age 50, vaccination even without a booster protected strongly against hospitalization and death, according to new C.D.C. data.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Thursday night published new data on the risks of hospitalization and death from Covid-19 among people who are unvaccinated and vaccinated, with or without booster doses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Jan. 6 Defendant Seeks to Subpoena Trump as Witness at Trial
description: The request to have the former president testify faces an uphill fight, but it illustrates efforts by defendants to place him at the center of their cases.
content: Almost from the moment that the first rioters were arrested in connection with the violent attack on the Capitol last January, defendants have tried in various ways to blame former President Donald J. Trump for their behavior.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Pie and Adam Westbrook
title: ‘The First Thing You Need to Know About Boris Johnson Is He’s a Liar’
description: To help make sense of the scandal surrounding Britain’s prime minister, we enlisted the help of satirical newscaster, Jonathan Pie.
content: Throughout the Covid-19 pandemic, British people have been largely law abiding and civic minded. They followed the stay-at-home orders through three lengthy lockdowns, many losing their jobs, missing birthdays, weddings and even the funerals of their loved ones in the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: The Warm, Sticky-Sweet Resurgence of Hotteok
description: Crisp and chewy on the outside, gooey on the inside, the popular street food feels nostalgic for some Korean Americans, novel to others.
content: The most challenging part of eating hotteok is the waiting, said the chef Judy Joo. It takes a few minutes for the hot sugar encased in the crisp, chewy pancakes to go from molten, burn-your-mouth-off goo to warm, sticky goodness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The Dissenters Trying to Save Evangelicalism From Itself
description: Heartbroken by the path their church has taken, they seek a renewal.
content: Think of your 12 closest friends. These are the people you vacation with, talk about your problems with, do life with in the most intimate and meaningful ways. Now imagine if six of those people suddenly took a political or public position you found utterly vile. Now imagine learning that those six people think that your position is utterly vile. You would suddenly realize that the people you thought you knew best and cared about most had actually been total strangers all along. You would feel disoriented, disturbed, unmoored. Your life would change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: David Gordon, a Wizard of Movement and Words, Dies at 85
description: For this choreographer, director and pioneer of postmodern dance, life was art and art was life.
content: David Gordon, the venerable, award-winning choreographer and director who was a founding member of the 1960s experimental collective Judson Dance Theater, died on Jan. 29 at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Rotunno
title: Over the Top, Out of the Ordinary, Valentine’s Day Gifts
description: Whether you seek to stick to traditions or go in a new direction, there are plenty of options.
content: Desire is not always practical or predictable. Why, then, should a gift from the heart be? If you’re giving someone a present this Valentine’s Day, consider over the top or out of the ordinary, which will only make your romantic gesture even more grand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: New Zealand Inquiry Finds Hundreds of Reports of Abuse by Priests
description: The complaints, going back seven decades, attest to the pervasiveness of sexual and other abuse within the Catholic Church and are part of a worldwide reckoning.
content: Reports of abuse were filed against hundreds of clergy members and others in the Roman Catholic Church in New Zealand dating back to the 1950s, according to figures released this week to a royal commission, which for the first time capture the pervasiveness of abuse accusations in the church there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Ana Swanson
title: House Passes Bill Adding Billions to Research to Compete With China
description: The vote sets up a fight with the Senate, which has different recommendations for how the United States should bolster its technology industry to take on China.
content: WASHINGTON — The House on Friday passed legislation that would pour nearly $300 billion into scientific research and development and shore up domestic manufacturing, setting up a dispute with the Senate over how best to invest in scientific innovation to strengthen American competitiveness and counter China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Jon Zazula, Early Promoter of Heavy Metal, Dies at 69
description: With his wife, Marsha, he founded Megaforce, a label that released the first albums of Metallica and others.
content: Jon Zazula, who with his wife, Marsha, founded Megaforce Records and was an important figure in the emergence of heavy metal music, giving Metallica, Anthrax and other bands their start, died on Tuesday at his home in Clermont, Fla. He was 69.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: The opening ceremony drew world leaders despite a U.S. diplomatic boycott.
description: Who came (Vladimir Putin) and who didn’t (Joe Biden) highlighted the world’s deepening ideological divisions.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin was there, rising out of his seat and waving to Russia’s team as it entered the Bird’s Nest. So were the leaders of the five Central Asian nations that were once part of the Soviet Union. The leaders of Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates came, even though they are hardly known for winter sports. Pakistan’s leader, Prime Minister Imran Kahn, announced his attendance on Twitter with a dramatic, masked photograph of himself and the words “Visit China.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: For Gambling Addicts, Super Bowl Betting Isn’t Good, Clean Fun
description: There has been a flood of online sports betting since the Supreme Court struck down limits in 2018.
content: Super Bowl LVI on Feb. 13 will be the first for which the National Football League has fully embraced gambling. Three bet takers — DraftKings, FanDuel and Caesars Entertainment — have been named official sports betting partners of the league. Four others — PointsBet, WynnBET, BetMGM and FOX Bet — have been designated approved sports book operators. It’s a big change for a league that once aggressively discouraged betting on games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The End of the Transfer Fee
description: With the vast majority of teams no longer able to pay stratospheric transfer fees, elite players are recalculating risk and reward on their terms.
content: The two transfers that drew all the oxygen from the summer of 2021 were both monuments to the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Talking Points With … Who Else? The Points Guy
description: Brian Kelly has been helping travelers and other consumers navigate the increasingly complicated loyalty universe for over a decade. Here’s what he has to say about playing the points game.
content: Brian Kelly, the founder of The Points Guy, a website devoted to maximizing credit card, airline and hotel loyalty points, was 12 in 1996 when he booked his first free trip, using his father’s points to arrange for the family of six to vacation in the Cayman Islands. Later, working as a recruiter for an investment bank, he began accumulating his own points for business travel, spending them on annual vacation sprees that so impressed his friends that he earned the nickname The Points Guy. In 2010, he began blogging under the name and, one year later, quit his day job to go full time into points hacking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: A Search Begins for the Wreck Behind an Epic Tale of Survival
description: Ernest Shackleton’s ship Endurance was crushed by Antarctic ice in 1915. Now, a team of researchers is heading to the Weddell Sea where it went down.
content: A century after Ernest Shackleton’s ship Endurance sank in the waters of Antarctica, resulting in one of the greatest survival stories in the history of exploration, a team of modern adventurers, technicians and scientists is setting sail to find the wreck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Lakin
title: From Graffiti to Gallery, Chris ‘Daze’ Ellis Lays New Tracks
description: His paintings at the contemporary gallery PPOW are a bridge to his train-tagging days and a paean to Bronx street life.
content: The Tribeca gallery PPOW, where Chris Ellis’s work is on view, sits around the corner from the old Mudd Club space, which in the late 1970s and early ’80s functioned as a clubhouse for New York City’s downtown demimonde. Graffiti writers from uptown and the outer boroughs mixed with art world habitués, and Keith Haring had the run of its fourth floor gallery. It was where Ellis, who began tagging trains as Daze in 1976, first showed his studio work indoors, a piece he made with Jean-Michel Basquiat for the 1981 show “Beyond Words,” curated by Leonard McGurr (a.k.a Futura) and Fred Brathwaite (a.k.a. Fab 5 Freddy).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
description: In this month’s picks, evil seizes a bathroom, cloaked cultists invade a small town and demons run amok just about everywhere else.
content: A family of four gathers in their spacious bathroom as a storm rages outside. The teen daughter (Sierra McCormick) anxiously texts someone who’s not responding. Her alcoholic dad (Pat Healy) is suspicious of who’s calling his wife (Vinessa Shaw). The little brother (John James Cronin) thinks a “giant tornado” is on the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
title: U.S. Covid Death Toll Surpasses 900,000 as Omicron’s Spread Slows
description: New case reports are waning, but deaths have yet to peak, and Americans are wondering what long-term coexistence with the coronavirus might look like.
content: CHICAGO — More than 2,600 Americans are dying from Covid-19 each day, an alarming rate that has climbed by 30 percent in the past two weeks. Across the United States, the coronavirus pandemic has now claimed more than 900,000 lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Ben Dooley
title: American Behind Carlos Ghosn Escape Is Ailing in Japanese Prison, Lawyers Say
description: Michael Taylor got frostbite in the unheated facility, his legal team says, as it pushes to have him and his son transferred to the United States.
content: After fleeing criminal charges in Tokyo two years ago, the former Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn waged a public campaign attacking the Japanese justice system, arguing that conditions in the country’s prisons were designed to “lead you to despair.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Spoke Spaniel
description: Joseph Greenbaum knows how to pack in those debut entries.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Joseph Greenbaum, in November, he was enjoying his second crossword byline after an auspicious debut on a Saturday in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: Over Spilled Champagne, a Spark
description: Kelly Frye was finalizing a divorce and doubtful she would ever find love again when she met Nick Campbell at a holiday party in London.
content: Kelly Frye was attending a holiday party in London on Dec. 5, 2019, when she saw the host accidentally spill a glass of champagne on Nick Campbell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Delta’s chief executive asks U.S. to bar unruly passengers from flying.
description: The request came in a letter to the attorney general after an increase in complaints about violent and disruptive passengers during the pandemic.
content: The chief executive of Delta Air Lines wants the federal government to put unruly passengers on a federal no-fly list that would bar them from commercial flights.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Tale of Pam and Tommy, and Weather Reporters Get Serious: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: North Carolina Court Says G.O.P. Political Maps Violate State Constitution
description: The State Supreme Court said maps of the state’s 14 House districts and state legislative districts violated guarantees of free elections, speech and assembly.
content: The North Carolina Supreme Court on Friday upended Republican efforts to lock in political dominance in the state, saying that congressional and state legislative maps were partisan gerrymanders that violated the State Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Adam Katzenstein
title: Could ‘White Noise’ Be Even More Ominous? Yes.
description: Reading Don DeLillo’s masterpiece while sitting in Los Angeles traffic adds an extra level of frisson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: How a Sports Bar Manager Spends Her Sundays
description: Abby Dowd, often with a megaphone, ministers to the football fans who call Blue Haven East “church.”
content: Some people go to Blue Haven East, a sports bar near Midtown, so religiously during football season that they call it church. One regular even had her baby shower there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: G.O.P. Lawsuit Casts N.Y. Congressional Maps as Brazen Gerrymandering
description: A Republican-led legal effort faces an uphill battle to overturn newly drawn congressional districts, which Democrats have defended as lawful.
content: A Republican-led group of voters filed a lawsuit late Thursday challenging New York’s freshly drawn congressional maps as unconstitutional, a day after Democratic lawmakers in Albany approved district lines that would heavily favor their party in its battle to retain control of the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn
title: Pandemic Era Tests May Speed Hepatitis-C Detection
description: A wave of diagnostics ushered in by Covid could help revive flagging efforts to eliminate the disease.
content: The Monday after Christmas, when Kellie Trent was scheduled to pick up medication to cure her hepatitis C, it seemed like a little miracle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Lipman and Jeffrey A. Sonnenfeld
title: Jeff Zucker and the Reckoning Over Office Romances
description: Corporate America needs to deal with the reality of office romances.
content: The headlines about the resignation of CNN’s president, Jeff Zucker, over his romantic relationship with a colleague are electrifying CNN’s defenders and antagonists alike and fueling endless speculation about possible corporate power plays behind the scenes. For those, like us, who have been writing for years about men, women and the workplace, this unfolding scandal also points out how difficult it is to regulate office romance and how unevenly corporate policies around consensual relationships are enforced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: A familiar face will again direct the opening ceremony in Beijing.
description: Zhang Yimou, who spearheaded the opening pageantry of the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, will do the same at this year’s Winter Games.
content: Nearly 14 years after China kicked off its first Olympics with a four-hour opening spectacle, the same man will be in charge of the pageantry of this year’s all-important opening ceremony: Zhang Yimou, an art house movie director who has evolved into a master of the grandiose, singing-dancing spectacles that are a centerpiece of Chinese political life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Piloting a Project: Tips and Handouts From Teachers Working With Our Profile Unit
description: Whether you’re participating in our contest or not, these useful ideas and adaptations can help you with any interview project.
content: When we introduce a new contest on our site, we always create resources to help teach with it. But we know those initial resources aren't enough. While everyone on our editorial staff is a former teacher, none of us are currently in the classroom — or have ever taught during a global pandemic. For real-world tweaks and tips, we count on the intrepid educators who are willing to pilot new curriculum, then tell us what happens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Anker
title: The Exploitation of ‘Freedom’ in America
description: America’s ugly history of distorting what the word means.
content: It would seem there is a lot of “freedom” being trumpeted by state officials these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Benveniste
title: A Brief History of Hightop Sneakers
description: In Wednesday’s puzzle, “hightop” was the answer to the clue “Style of sneaker.”
content: This is Clued In, a column that will give you insight into some of the New York Times Crossword clues and answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: From Liverpool to London, Tighter Wallets and Colder Homes
description: In Britain, prices are rising at the fastest pace in three decades. People on the lowest incomes are running out of ways to cut back, and the worst is yet to come.
content: LIVERPOOL, England — For the past few weeks Vincent Snowball hasn’t needed to use the weekly food bank that runs out of a church near Liverpool’s city center. But he’s still there each Tuesday, laying out fabric swatches to advertise his upholstering services, and to socialize with the people he grew up with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Russian Troops in Final Stages of Readiness Add to Worries for Ukraine
description: Though the Kremlin’s intentions are unclear, Ukrainian officials are newly worried about the Crimean Peninsula, where Russia has deployed 10,000 additional troops, they said.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — While the Russian military is not yet capable of mounting a total invasion of Ukraine, portions of its army have reached full combat strength and appear to be in the final stages of readiness for military action should the Kremlin order it, according to an assessment by the Ukrainian military’s high command.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: The Winter Show, Postponed Because of Omicron Surge, Sets April Dates
description: One of New York City’s leading art fairs will be set on five floors of the former Barneys flagship location on Madison Avenue.
content: The Winter Show’s 68th edition will run from April 1 through April 10 inside the former flagship location of Barneys New York at 660 Madison Avenue, the art fair’s organizers announced Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Sophie Kasakove
title: A Tenacious Winter Storm Moves Across the Northeast
description: The three-day storm left grounded planes and power outages across a 2,000-mile stretch of the country. A fatal crash in Texas stranded drivers for 10 hours on an icy highway.
content: A tenacious winter storm that stranded travelers, closed schools and snarled roadways as it swept from New Mexico to New England this week continued to bring hazardous weather on Friday, dumping a mix of snow, sleet and ice on parts of the Northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: The Housing Situation Is Dire. But Progress Is Still Possible.
description: In the South Bronx, developers found ways to build an array of sleek, affordable apartments in two subsidized housing developments. Is this a way forward?
content: Good news is hard to come by on the housing front. The eviction moratorium has expired. Experts now predict skyrocketing home prices may rise indefinitely. According to a Pew study, more American adults today consider affordable housing a major worry in their communities than crime, drugs or Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jamal Greene
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jamal Greene. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Jamal Greene. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Zero Covid in China
description: China’s zero-Covid policy has kept deaths very low. Can it continue?
content: World leaders are increasingly deciding that their countries need to figure out how to live with Covid-19 rather than minimize the number of cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: A Black Iraqi’s Sudden Career in TV News: ‘They Wanted to See All Colors’
description: Randa Abd Al-Aziz was joking with friends in a Baghdad cafe when she got a surprise job offer: broadcasting the news in Iraq, whose Black citizens have little media presence and even less power.
content: BAGHDAD — Randa Abd Al-Aziz was relaxing in a Baghdad cafe, making her friends laugh by reading a cosmetics pamphlet aloud in classical Arabic, the exaggeratedly formal language of speeches, official decrees — and TV anchors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maura Elizabeth Cunningham
title: The 2022 Olympics Are Already a Win for China
description: The Communist Party doesn’t need foreign approval to mark these Games in the column of its domestic successes.
content: The Beijing Summer Games in 2008 started out with a bang — thousands of fireworks shot from the rim of the Bird’s Nest stadium and exploded against the night sky, briefly turning the structure into a giant replica of the Olympic Torch. The stunning pyrotechnics show capped off an opening ceremony designed not only to wow but also to make a statement: China has arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The festivities get a new shirtless, oiled-up athlete.
description: Nathan Crumpton competes in skeleton for American Samoa.
content: Fans of oiled-up, shirtless Pacific islanders seemed destined to be disappointed after the Tongan taekwondo and cross-country skiing athlete Pita Taufatofua, hero of 2016, ’18 and the Tokyo Games last year, said he would not be coming to the Beijing Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Besha Rodell
title: Why I’ve Learned to Loathe Australia’s Trivial Politics
description: This week has shown just how ill-equipped the current Australian political ecosystem is when facing catastrophe.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Before the U.S. election in 2016, I visited Australia from Los Angeles, where I was living at the time. I stayed with my father at his house in northern New South Wales, and like a lot of older Australians, he had his television tuned to the news almost constantly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Oregon Church Sues City That Limited Soup Kitchen Hours
description: St. Timothy’s Episcopal Church in Brookings, Ore., is challenging a new municipal ordinance that limits church soup kitchen programs to two days a week.
content: With each new valley confronting poor Americans during the coronavirus pandemic, the soup kitchen lines outside St. Timothy’s Episcopal Church in Brookings, Ore., have remained steady, the comfort of a hot meal drawing the area’s most marginalized to the parish up to four times a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The C.D.C. adds wastewater data to its Covid-19 tracker.
description: Analyzing wastewater can help officials estimate how prevalent the virus is in a community and which variants are circulating.
content: More than a year after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention established its National Wastewater Surveillance System, the agency added wastewater data to its Covid-19 data tracker on Friday, providing a quick glimpse of whether the levels of coronavirus are rising or falling in hundreds of communities across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: India may be emerging from its latest surge, health officials say.
description: “We are seeing the pandemic situation has improved,” said Dr. V.K. Paul, the head of India’s Covid task force.
content: NEW DELHI — After weeks of a coronavirus surge most likely fueled by the highly transmissible Omicron variant, Indian health officials said that the number of cases appeared to be declining, even as daily numbers remained high in some parts of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: From Chad, a Filmmaker and a Star Committed to Telling Stories of Home
description: In “Lingui, the Sacred Bonds,” the director Mahamat-Saleh Haroun works again with Achouackh Abakar Souleymane, this time on a wrenching drama about abortion.
content: As Chad’s most lauded auteur, the director Mahamat-Saleh Haroun remains committed to portraying his sub-Saharan African homeland onscreen. Early in his career he focused on the fallout from the nation’s multiple civil wars, which forced him to migrate to France in the 1980s. But in the aftermath of the conflict that concluded in 2010, he has shifted his attention to other social ills.
source.name: The New York Times

title: In photos: Figure skating kicks off in Beijing with team competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mandelbaum
title: If Rover Can Make It Here, Perhaps Bald Eagles Can Make It Anywhere
description: A white-headed raptor has been preying on smaller birds in Central Park. It’s come a long way since conservationists affixed aluminum bands to its legs four years ago.
content: Visitors to Central Park’s reservoir in New York are taking in a drama filled with feathers. Its star performer, thrilling parkgoers and terrorizing gulls, is Rover, a bald eagle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: These Bold Mushrooms Are Ready to Meet the Moment
description: Portobellos served atop a versatile chile-bell pepper sauce and finished with corn nuts are perfect for 2022, Yotam Ottolenghi writes.
content: LONDON — Sometimes, when my test kitchen crew and I create a new dish, we do it to fit a greater narrative: the story of a season or of a day, about the person who inspired the dish, or a particular ingredient.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Need a Life Coach? This 5-Year-Old Can Help.
description: A child’s advice for coping with anxiety has gone viral after his mother shared it on Twitter. (Hint: It involves doughnuts, dinosaurs and Dolly Parton.)
content: For 5-year-old Clark Todebush, the transition to kindergarten after two years of pandemic isolation hasn’t been easy. Sometimes he cries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: The famed Tongan flag-bearer won’t attend the Games.
description: Pita Taufatofua, a three-time Olympian, is focused instead on the disaster response to a powerful tsunami that struck his island nation.
content: Pita Taufatofua, a Tongan athlete perhaps best known for his role as a shirtless and oiled flag-bearer, will not compete in the 2022 Winter Olympics — to the disappointment of loyal opening ceremony viewers who had hoped for his gleaming return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: It’s a Boom Year for Brides and Grooms
description: If the predictions pan out, there will be some 2.5 million weddings in 2022 — the most since 1984 — and yet it’s never been more difficult to plan one. Here’s what couples should expect.
content: Rest assured, romantics: All the weddings canceled over the last couple of years have found a happy home, and that home is … 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Andrew Das
title: In a provocative choice, China picks an athlete with a Uyghur name to help light the cauldron.
description: The pick seemed intended to answer criticisms of China’s mass detention and re-education campaign targeting Uyghur Muslims in the western region of Xinjiang.
content: In a climactic moment to end the opening ceremony of the 2022 Winter Olympics, China chose two athletes — including one it said was of Uyghur heritage — to deliver the flame to the Olympic cauldron and officially start the Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung and Lauren McCarthy
title: A Missouri health official is the latest vaccine proponent to be pushed out.
description: Donald Kauerauf was forced from office in another example of politicized fighting over masks, mandates and pandemic response.
content: Missouri’s top health official, a Republican who opposes mask and vaccine mandates but spoke approvingly of the Covid vaccine, was supposed to have been confirmed by State Senate by Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: In a Divisive Games, an Opening Ceremony in Search of Unity
description: There was the usual pageantry and symbols of togetherness, at a Games walled off from its host city because of the pandemic.
content: BEIJING — Thousands of performers skipped and gyrated on a 125,000-square-foot, high-definition LED stage programmed to resemble a sheet of shimmering ice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: More Thoughts on America’s Feel-Bad Boom
description: Inflation aversion meets the partisan economy.
content: By the numbers, 2021 was a boom year for the U.S. economy. Back in 2020 many forecasters expected a sluggish recovery, with unemployment staying high for years. Instead, unemployment has already come down almost to prepandemic levels, and a record percentage of Americans say that this is a good time to find a quality job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Ghost Army, a World War II Master of Deception, Finally Wins Recognition
description: President Biden signed a bill that bestows the Congressional Gold Medal to the members of “a traveling roadshow of deception” that built inflatable tanks and trucks to trick the Germans.
content: The Ghost Army had one goal: Deceive Hitler’s forces and their allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: U.S. broadcast prime-time coverage on Friday includes figure skating, snowboarding and hockey.
description: A package version of the opening ceremony, including the lighting of the cauldron, will also air on NBC.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Friday with figure skating, snowboarding and hockey. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diana Tsui
title: A Fashionable Start to the Lunar New Year
description: Phillip Lim hosted an intimate dinner at the Genesis House for friends and fellow designers.
content: “It feels like my wedding,” said the designer Phillip Lim on Tuesday night, as he greeted about 40 guests to a highly art-directed, made-for-Instagram dinner celebrating the Lunar New Year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Reid J. Epstein
title: G.O.P. Declares Jan. 6 Attack ‘Legitimate Political Discourse’
description: The Republican National Committee voted to censure Representatives Liz Cheney and Adam Kinzinger for participating in the inquiry into the deadly riot at the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — The Republican Party on Friday officially declared the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol and events that led to it “legitimate political discourse,” and rebuked two lawmakers in the party who have been most outspoken in condemning the deadly riot and the role of Donald J. Trump in spreading the election lies that fueled it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Morris
title: For a Composer at 90, There’s Nothing but Time
description: For decades, Éliane Radigue has created a great deal of slow, very minimal, mostly electronic music.
content: Éliane Radigue lives and works in a second-floor apartment in the Montparnasse neighborhood of Paris. A weeping fig tree looms above her head; across the loft-like room are three large windows adorned with house plants. The windows face a school across the street which, she wrote in a recent email, “gives its rhythm to days, weeks and months.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: James Bidgood, Master of Erotic Gay Photography, Dies at 88
description: In addition to his elaborately staged images of gay fantasies, he made the film “Pink Narcissus,” a cult classic released anonymously in 1971.
content: James Bidgood, who elevated erotic gay photography to an art in the 1960s and ’70s with his carefully staged phantasmagoric pictures, and who was the anonymous director behind “Pink Narcissus,” a gay film released in 1971 that became something of a cult classic, died on Jan. 31 in Manhattan. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Chiefs of AT&T and Discovery address Jeff Zucker’s resignation
description: John Stankey, the head of AT&T, and David Zaslav, the chief of Discovery, sidestepped intense speculation regarding whether Mr. Zucker was forced out.
content: The chief executives of AT&T and Discovery, in their first public comments since the abrupt resignation of Jeff Zucker as president of CNN this week, acknowledged the upheaval at the network but sought to paint a picture of a powerful news brand that could succeed without its longtime chief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Russian athletes again make an appearance as R.O.C.
description: The country is still barred from international competitions, but some of its athletes are allowed to participate.
content: Russia is still banned from the Olympics, but hundreds of its athletes are still set to compete in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: They Rushed to Buy in the Pandemic. Here’s What They Would Change.
description: A frenzied sellers’ market led some people to make harried decisions when buying their homes that they now regret.
content: For nearly two years, home buyers have been shopping in conditions ripe for regret. Prices have soared, inventory has plunged and competition has been brutal in markets across the country. With fixer-uppers fetching multiple offers, buyers must make snap decisions about what is often the biggest financial investment of their lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Strong Jobs Report Shows Resilient Economy Despite Covid Wave
description: A gain of 467,000 jobs in January defied forecasts that the Omicron variant would hobble the labor market.
content: A record-setting spike in coronavirus cases kept millions of workers at home in January and disrupted businesses from coast to coast. But it couldn’t knock the U.S. job-market recovery off course.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: I’m Cold. Where Can I Find a Stylish Coat?
description: A reader, no longer interested in fur and wary of wool, seeks guidance on keeping warm while staying fashionable.
content: As death and taxes are to life — absolute certainties — so, too, is the fact that if once upon a time an item of clothing was regarded as absolutely out of fashion, fashion will rediscover it and find a way to make it chic. Case in point: the puffer coat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: At the Philharmonic, Enveloping and Harrowing Sincerity
description: With the countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo, the orchestra offered a sustained, serious reflection on love and its loss.
content: Last week at the New York Philharmonic, winking and sincerity mingled. Mashing Gluck and Peter Gabriel, Rossini and Jobim, in a big chunk of their duo show “Only an Octave Apart,” the countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo and the cabaret star Justin Vivian Bond were poignant — and hilarious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘My Year Abroad’ and ‘Amoralman’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: THE MAN WHO ATE TOO MUCH: The Life of James Beard, by John Birdsall. (Norton, 480 pp., $20.) The food writer John Birdsall, who has a knack for “the single perfectly placed word,” according to our reviewer, Ligaya Mishan, takes on the life and culinary feats of James Beard in this comprehensive and delectable biography. “Birdsall’s sentences have rhythm, too, and compress time and place so that a meal becomes a history.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Hate Crimes Trial to Proceed After Arbery Killers Withdraw Guilty Pleas
description: Gregory and Travis McMichael had previously agreed to plead guilty, but a federal judge rejected the deal, which offered 30-year sentences. Jury selection is set to begin on Monday.
content: ATLANTA — Travis and Gregory McMichael, two of the three men convicted in state court of murdering Ahmaud Arbery, have withdrawn guilty pleas in their federal hate crimes case, clearing the way for a trial that will once again revisit the afternoon two years ago when they chased Mr. Arbery, a Black man, through their South Georgia neighborhood, a chase that ended with three shotgun blasts, and Mr. Arbery dead on the pavement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penn Bullock
title: Republicans, Olympics, Secondhand Clothing: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam and Blake Hounshell
title: The Politics of Gloom
description: Some voters aren’t sold on the idea that an election will save them from their anguish.
content: Earlier this week, 10 women from across the country met on Zoom and talked for two hours as part of a focus group on politics. All of the women were white, lived in the suburbs and had been identified as swing voters. One was a mother from Iowa who owns a small business. Another teaches special education in Florida. And there was a school bus driver from Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Claressa Shields Is a Champion. Now, She May Finally Be Paid as One.
description: Shields has a two-fight deal, starting with Saturday’s bout against Ema Kozin of Slovenia, that could vault her into the pay bracket of similarly credentialed male fighters.
content: Claressa Shields looked into her phone’s camera lens to make eye contact, then held up an index finger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘She Interviews Celebrities Before School. And She’s Only 11.’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about a young journalist who has talked with Alicia Keys, Tom Holland and Jay-Z. Who is your dream celebrity to interview?
content: This lesson is a part of our Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Mystery Money
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this photo — or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Smithsonian Names First Director of Museum of the American Latino
description: Jorge Zamanillo, the chief executive of a community-based Miami history museum, will lead the new institution, which Congress authorized in late 2020.
content: The National Museum of the American Latino, a new Smithsonian institution, is at least a decade away from opening. As of yet, it has no budget. No building. No collection. But it now has its first permanent director, Jorge Zamanillo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Which Figure Skaters Have a Good Shot at Gold?
description: The men’s individual competition features a familiar American-Japanese duel, while the women’s singles will probably be dominated by Russians.
content: Olympic figure skating began Friday morning in Beijing with the team event, in which men’s and women’s singles skaters, pairs and ice dancers all compete and combine their scores for their countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: ‘The Answer Is Not to Abandon Our Streets’
description: President Biden outlines his strategy for helping New York accelerate the fight against gun violence.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at the strategies that President Biden outlined to help New York City fight gun violence. We’ll also look at the continuing fallout from the resignation of former Gov. Andrew Cuomo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: News Corp says journalists’ emails were hacked in an attack linked to China.
description: The news publishing company said it thought the breach affected a “limited number” of accounts.
content: News Corp, the news publishing empire owned by Rupert Murdoch, was the target of a cyberattack that hacked the email accounts of journalists and others at the company, in a breach that a digital security firm said was meant to help China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: What Would You Write a Book About?
description: Do you ever write stories and share them with others?
content: Do you enjoy storytelling? Do you like hearing your family member’s stories about growing up? Do you like telling your friends and family stories, whether real or make believe?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda M. Fairbanks
title: Scandal on a Wealthy Island: A Priest, a Murder and a Mystery
description: The Rev. Canon Paul Wancura led a quiet, privileged life. But after his shocking death, a sexual abuse allegation followed.
content: Not much happens of note on Shelter Island, all 8,000 bucolic acres of it. Sandwiched between Long Island’s North and South Forks, it’s the kind of place where people seem to know one another, where car doors are often left unlocked and where, for some 20 years, the most bothersome problem has been Lyme disease-carrying blacklegged ticks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: With Their First Kiss, ‘Life Turned to Technicolor’
description: After meeting at an event for a group devoted to the professional advancement of women, Claire Wasserman and Ashley Louise soon advanced from collaborators to romantic partners.
content: In October 2016, Ashley Lynn Louise attended a town-hall meeting given by Ladies Get Paid, an educational and networking organization devoted to the professional advancement of women. She was so moved by the event that after it ended she ran up to Claire Sarah Wasserman, its moderator, and told her, “I really want to help.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Diagramless
description: Alex Eaton-Salners makes a mean (really mean!) motivational speech.
content: DIAGRAMLESS — This little variety puzzle might be the hardest thing on offer from The New York Times’s Games department, and the grid by Alex Eaton-Salners just about defeated me. Fortunately, diagramless puzzles are always creative and fun; a design reveals itself slowly, helped (or sometimes sabotaged) by hints in its clue set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Manhattan D.A. Sharpens Crime Policies That Led to Weeks of Backlash
description: Alvin Bragg clarified policies on robbery and gun possession that had prompted widespread pushback, marring his first month in office.
content: Taking a tougher stance on the prosecution of gun possession and robbery, the Manhattan district attorney on Friday officially revised several policies that had been fiercely criticized as too lenient, marring his first month in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Twohey and Gabriel J.X. Dance
title: Lawmakers Press Amazon on Sales of Chemical Used in Suicides
description: Even as grieving families tried to warn Amazon and other e-commerce sites of the danger, there were more purchases and more deaths.
content: The pleas to Amazon were explicit. A food preservative sold by the online retailer and other e-commerce sites was being used as a poison to die by suicide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What Will Move Markets Now?
description: Meta’s earnings led to a wild swing in stocks. The latest jobs numbers might trigger another.
content: Last week, markets swung wildly on economic news, as investors tried to interpret signals from the Fed about inflation and interest rates. This week, corporate earnings took the spotlight, and things looked steadier — for a while.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walter Kirn
title: Heather Havrilesky Compares Her Husband to a Heap of Laundry
description: In her memoir, “Foreverland,” the advice columnist opens up about her own marriage.
content: FOREVERLANDOn the Divine Tedium of MarriageBy Heather HavrileskySometimes the dedication of a book is integral to understanding it. “Foreverland,” a memoir of a marriage that proposes to illuminate marriage itself, is dedicated simply “To Bill,” the husband of Heather Havrilesky, its author, who pays him this brief honor as a prelude to writing endlessly about his flaws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Georgetown Law, Don’t Punish Your New Hire Over His ‘Lesser Black Woman’ Tweet
description: This is a terrible time for liberal institutions to weaken academic freedom.
content: A libertarian constitutional law scholar named Ilya Shapiro sent out some ugly tweets last week. Shapiro, who’d recently been hired by Georgetown University’s law school, criticized Joe Biden’s pledge to nominate a Black woman to the Supreme Court, arguing that the Indian-born judge Sri Srinivasan was “objectively” the “best pick.” But Srinivasan, wrote Shapiro, “alas doesn’t fit into latest intersectionality hierarchy so we’ll get lesser black woman.” He claimed that if Biden considered only Black women, whoever he chose would always have an “asterisk attached.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Yale Kamisar, Known as the ‘Father’ of the Miranda Rule, Dies at 92
description: His legal scholarship, cited in more than 30 Supreme Court cases, shaped modern criminal procedure, including protections for the rights of the accused.
content: Yale Kamisar, a legal scholar whose work on civil liberties and criminal procedure had a profound influence on landmark Supreme Court decisions like Gideon v. Wainwright and Miranda v. Arizona, died on Sunday at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: What’s in a name? For Taiwan, a lot.
description: Officials from the self-governing island worry that China might use the Games as a linguistic opportunity to assert its claim over Taiwan.
content: A week ago, Taiwan said it would not participate in the opening ceremony of the Winter Games in Beijing. Then the island democracy reversed its decision, citing pressure from the International Olympic Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: The Nation’s Top Scorer Plays for a School and a People
description: Ryan Turell leads all N.C.A.A. basketball players in scoring and hopes to play in the N.B.A. But first, he plans to prove that Yeshiva, a small Jewish university, is as good as its record.
content: They lined up for blocks along Amsterdam Avenue in December, standing in the cold for two hours, hoping to squeeze into the modest Max Stern Athletic Center for a glimpse at the hottest college basketball team in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Overlooked No More: Ora Washington, Star of Tennis and Basketball
description: She was dominant in both sports over two decades and was in all likelihood the first Black star in women’s sports in the United States.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Renate Reinsve Steps, Reluctantly, Into the Spotlight
description: The Norwegian actress was ready to quit the business before she was cast as the lead in “The Worst Person in the World.” Now she’s navigating newfound fame.
content: At a dinner during the Cannes Film Festival in July, Renate Reinsve found herself so nervous in the company of famous actors that she spent the evening chatting with their bodyguards instead. When a photographer who had been taking pictures of Timothée Chalamet appeared near the group, she said, her new friends waved him over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum

content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Are Billionaires Making Out Like Bandits?
description: Rising wealth may not be quite what it seems.
content: Did you hear about Jeff Bezos and the bridge? The Amazon billionaire’s new superyacht, under construction in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, is so big that the city might have to partially take down a historic bridge so that it can reach open water. The story has quickly become a metaphor for soaring inequality, and it feeds the perception that billionaires have done very well during the Covid-19 pandemic while ordinary people have suffered.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An act of selflessness earns a U.S. speedskater a flag-bearing role.
description: Brittany Bowe was named one of the U.S. flag-bearers after the bobsledder Elana Meyers Taylor, who was originally chosen, tested positive for the coronavirus after arriving in Beijing.
content: Brittany Bowe was named one of the U.S. flag-bearers after the bobsledder Elana Meyers Taylor, who was originally chosen, tested positive for the coronavirus after arriving in Beijing.

title: Nathan Chen finishes first in skating’s team event, setting up the U.S. for a medal.
description: Chen skated in the short program, his first event in Beijing, and rebounded from a disappointing showing at the 2018 Games.
content: With seamless footwork and high-flying quadruple jumps, Nathan Chen, the gold medal favorite in figure skating’s men’s singles event, easily finished first on Friday in the men’s short program of the team event, giving the U.S. team an edge to win an early medal at the Beijing Games.
source.name: The New York Times
